subject: RE: [junit] Preventing JUnit from stopping on failures.
msgSnippet: When I write tests like this (where the arrangement before the act is somewhat complicated), I will put the precondition assertions in my tests.  My reason for
messageBody:
When I write tests like this (where the arrangement before the act is
somewhat complicated), I will put the precondition assertions in my
tests. My reason for doing this is that if something goes wrong with
the arrangement, then the test fails with better information about what
really went wrong. Sure, I may have other tests that do the same
arrangement and have the same assertion, but if both tests are going to
fail for the same reason, then it's nice for the failure report to have
the same reason listed twice--then you know for certain that there's
only one root problem causing the failures.

This pattern actually brings up an interesting point, though. If one of
my precondition assertions fails, I really don't want to continue with
the "act" portion of the test. If one of my postcondition assertions
fails, I could see a case for allowing the test to continue for more
complete information. The problem is that a single test now has some
assertions that should halt the test if they fail and others that
shouldn't. To accomplish this, you'd really need two types of
assertions. I personally think that it's just fine to halt the test at
the first failed assertion. If unit tests are so expensive to run that
you avoid it, then you really have bigger problems than just incomplete
failure information.

..David..

To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Preventing JUnit from stopping on failures.


J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> I thought I saw this pattern in your example:
>
> arrange
> act
> assert
> act some more
> assert some more
> act some more
> assert some more
>
You are correct in that you "mis-saw". It was:

arrange
assert pre-conditions
act
assert post-conditions

The "assert pre-conditions" was only for the sake of clarity in the
post. This of course would have be done elsewhere (in a construction
test) so that the testApplyCreditMemo() would not have needed to check
it.
